MATCH (john:Person {name: 'John'})
MATCH (john)-[:FRIEND]->(friend)
RETURN friend.name AS friendName

cypher:
MATCH (j:Person {name: 'John'})-[:FRIEND]->(f)
SET f.degreesFromJohn = 1
MATCH (f)-[:FRIEND]->(f2)
SET f2.degreesFromJohn = f.degreesFromJohn + 1
RETURN f.name AS friendName, 
       f.degreesFromJohn AS friendDegree, 
       f2.name AS friendOfFriendName, 
       f2.degreesFromJohn AS friendOfFriendDegree
description: This section describes the semantics of Cypher when composing different read and write clauses.

cypher:

cypher:
MATCH (john:Person {name: 'John'})
SET john.friends = []
WITH john
MATCH (john)-[:FRIEND]->(friend)
WITH john, friend
CALL (john, friend) {
  WITH john.friends AS friends
  SET john.friends = friends + friend.name
}
description: This section describes the semantics of Cypher when composing different read and write clauses.

       (hannah)-[:BUYS {date: date('2024-06-02')}]->(headphones),
       (leila)-[:BUYS {date: date('2023-05-17')}]->(laptop),
       (niko)-[:BUYS {date: date('2025-02-27')}]->(phone),
       (niko)-[:BUYS {date: date('2024-08-23')}]->(headphones),

cypher:
MATCH (p:Product)
LET isExpensive = p.price >= 500
LET isAffordable = NOT isExpensive
LET discountCategory = CASE 
    WHEN isExpensive THEN 'High-end'
    ELSE 'Budget'
END
RETURN p.name AS product, p.price AS price, isAffordable, discountCategory
ORDER BY price
description: Information about Cypher's `LET` clause.

cypher:
MATCH (p:Product)
WITH p, p.price >= 500 AS isExpensive
WITH p, isExpensive, NOT isExpensive AS isAffordable
WITH p, isExpensive, isAffordable, 
     CASE 
         WHEN isExpensive THEN 'High-end' 
         ELSE 'Budget' 
     END AS discountCategory
RETURN p.name AS product, p.price AS price, isAffordable, discountCategory
ORDER BY price
description: Information about Cypher's `LET` clause.

cypher:
MATCH (c:Customer)-[:BUYS]->(p:Product)
WITH DISTINCT c, sum(p.price) AS totalSpent
RETURN c.firstName AS customer, totalSpent
description: Information about Cypher's `LET` clause.

cypher:
MATCH (c:Customer)-[:BUYS]->(p:Product)
WITH DISTINCT c, sum(p.price) AS totalSpent
LET fullName = c.firstName + ' ' + c.lastName
RETURN fullName, totalSpent
description: Information about Cypher's `LET` clause.

cypher:
MATCH (c:Customer)-[b:BUYS]->(p:Product)<--(s:Supplier)
LET fullname = c.firstName + ' ' + c.lastName,
    effectivePrice = p.price * (1 - c.discount)
LET message = fullname + " bought " + p.name + " for $" + effectivePrice + " after a " + (c.discount * 100) + "% discount"
RETURN b.date AS date, message, s.email AS toSupplier
ORDER BY date
description: Information about Cypher's `LET` clause.

     END AS discountCategory
RETURN p.name AS product,
       p.price AS price,
       isAffordable,
       discountCategory

cypher:
MATCH p = (a:Person {name: $fromName})-[:KNOWS*1..3]-(b:Person {name: $toName})
RETURN p, length(p) AS hops
ORDER BY hops ASC
description: Find all paths up to 3 hops between two people using bounded variable-length relationships

cypher:
MATCH p = shortestPath(
  (a:Person {name: $fromName})-[:KNOWS*]-(b:Person {name: $toName})
)
WHERE ALL(n IN nodes(p) WHERE n.status = 'active')
RETURN p, length(p) AS hops
description: Find the shortest path between two people, excluding any path that passes through inactive nodes using an ALL predicate filter

cypher:
MATCH p = allShortestPaths(
  (src:Warehouse {code: $sourceCode})-[:SHIPS_TO*]-(dst:Warehouse {code: $destCode})
)
RETURN p, length(p) AS legs,
       [n IN nodes(p) | n.code] AS route
description: Find all shortest routes between two warehouses in a supply chain, returning the route codes for each equally-short path

cypher:
MATCH p = (a:Location {name: $fromLocation})-[:ROUTE*1..6]-(b:Location {name: $toLocation})
WHERE ALL(r IN relationships(p) WHERE r.weight > $minWeight)
RETURN p,
       REDUCE(total = 0.0, r IN relationships(p) | total + r.weight) AS totalWeight
ORDER BY totalWeight DESC
LIMIT 10
description: Find paths where every relationship exceeds a weight threshold, computing total weight across the path using REDUCE

cypher:
MATCH p = (a:Account)-[:TRANSFERRED_TO*2..6]->(a)
WHERE ALL(r IN relationships(p) WHERE r.amount > $minAmount)
WITH p, [r IN relationships(p) | r.txId] AS txIds,
     REDUCE(total = 0.0, r IN relationships(p) | total + r.amount) AS cycleTotal
RETURN txIds, cycleTotal, length(p) AS chainLength
ORDER BY cycleTotal DESC
LIMIT 25
description: Detect circular transaction chains (fraud pattern) where money flows through a cycle back to the originating account, filtering by minimum transfer amount

cypher:
MATCH pShortest = shortestPath(
  (a:Person {name: $fromName})-[:KNOWS*]-(b:Person {name: $toName})
)
WITH a, b, length(pShortest) AS shortLen
MATCH pAll = (a)-[:KNOWS*1..6]-(b)
WITH pAll, shortLen, length(pAll) AS pathLen
WHERE pathLen <= shortLen + 2
RETURN pAll, pathLen, shortLen
ORDER BY pathLen ASC
LIMIT 20
description: Compare shortest path length against all paths between two nodes, returning paths that are at most 2 hops longer than the shortest

cypher:
MATCH p = shortestPath(
  (src:City {name: $fromCity})-[:CONNECTED_TO*]-(dst:City {name: $toCity})
)
UNWIND nodes(p) AS stop
WITH stop, p
WHERE stop <> nodes(p)[0] AND stop <> nodes(p)[-1]
RETURN stop.name AS intermediateCity,
       stop.population AS population,
       length(p) AS totalHops
ORDER BY stop.population DESC
description: Extract and analyze all intermediate nodes along a shortest path by unwinding path nodes, excluding start and end

cypher:
MATCH p = (src:Airport {iata: $fromIATA})-[:FLIGHT*1..4]-(dst:Airport {iata: $toIATA})
WITH p,
     REDUCE(cost = 0, r IN relationships(p) | cost + r.price) AS totalCost,
     REDUCE(dur = duration({minutes: 0}), r IN relationships(p) | dur + r.duration) AS totalDuration
RETURN [n IN nodes(p) | n.iata] AS route,
       totalCost,
       totalDuration
ORDER BY totalCost ASC
LIMIT 5
description: Find the minimum-cost route between airports by using REDUCE to sum relationship prices across variable-length paths, also computing total duration

cypher:
CALL ()
{
  MATCH (p:Product)
  WHERE p.lastReview < date($cutoffDate)
  SET p.needsReview = true
} IN TRANSACTIONS OF 500 ROWS
RETURN count(*) AS updatedCount
description: Batch update a large number of product nodes using CALL IN TRANSACTIONS to avoid memory pressure, processing 500 nodes per transaction

cypher:
MATCH (c:Customer)
WHERE EXISTS {
  MATCH (c)-[:PURCHASED]->(o:Order)-[:CONTAINS]->(p:Product)
  WHERE p.category = $category AND o.total > $minTotal
}
RETURN c.name AS customer, c.email AS email
ORDER BY c.name
description: Filter customers using an EXISTS predicate subquery to find those who purchased products in a specific category above a minimum order total

cypher:
MATCH (u:User)
CALL (u)
{
  MATCH (u)<-[:FOLLOWS]-(follower:User)
  RETURN count(follower) AS followerCount
}
RETURN u.username AS username,
       followerCount
ORDER BY followerCount DESC
LIMIT 20
description: Correlated subquery to compute per-user follower counts in a social network, returning the top 20 most-followed users

cypher:
MATCH (dept:Department {name: $deptName})
CALL (dept)
{
  MATCH (dept)<-[:WORKS_IN]-(e:Employee)
  RETURN e.name AS name, 'employee' AS type
  UNION
  MATCH (dept)<-[:CONTRACTS_FOR]-(c:Contractor)
  RETURN c.name AS name, 'contractor' AS type
}
RETURN name, type
ORDER BY name
description: UNION subquery combining employees and contractors belonging to a department into a single result set with a type discriminator

cypher:
MATCH (cat:Category)
CALL (cat)
{
  MATCH (cat)<-[:IN_CATEGORY]-(p:Product)
  WITH p
  ORDER BY p.revenue DESC
  LIMIT 3
  RETURN p
}
RETURN cat.name AS category,
       p.name AS product,
       p.revenue AS revenue
ORDER BY cat.name, revenue DESC
description: Top-N per group pattern: retrieve the top 3 highest-revenue products per category using a correlated subquery with ORDER BY and LIMIT
Neo4j 5.x COUNT expression used inline to filter actors with at least N movies since a given year, and project the count in the RETURN clause

cypher:
MATCH (a:Actor {name: $actor1})-[:ACTED_IN]->(m:Movie)<-[:ACTED_IN]-(b:Actor {name: $actor2})
RETURN m.title AS commonMovie, m.released AS year
ORDER BY m.released DESC
description: 2-hop join via shared node: finds all movies two actors have both appeared in by traversing through the shared Movie node.

cypher:
MATCH (p1:Person {name: $person1})-[:KNOWS]->(mutual)<-[:KNOWS]-(p2:Person {name: $person2})
RETURN count(mutual) AS sharedConnections
description: 2-hop join with count: counts the number of mutual acquaintances between two people by matching shared KNOWS relationships.

cypher:
MATCH (me:Customer {id: $customerId})-[:FRIENDS_WITH]->(friend)-[:FRIENDS_WITH]->(fof:Customer)
WHERE fof <> me AND NOT (me)-[:FRIENDS_WITH]->(fof)
MATCH (fof)-[:REVIEWED]->(p:Product)<-[:REVIEWED]-(me)
RETURN DISTINCT fof.name AS friendOfFriend, collect(p.name) AS commonProducts
ORDER BY size(commonProducts) DESC
LIMIT 10
description: 3-hop join: discovers friends-of-friends who reviewed the same products you did, useful for recommendation engines.

cypher:
MATCH (p:Person)-[:MEMBER_OF]->(g:Group)
WHERE g.name IN $groupNames
WITH p, collect(DISTINCT g.name) AS memberGroups
WHERE size(memberGroups) = size($groupNames)
RETURN p.name AS person, memberGroups
description: Set intersection using COLLECT: finds people who belong to ALL specified groups by collecting their memberships and comparing the count to the input list size.

cypher:
MATCH (target:Product {id: $productId})<-[:PURCHASED]-(c:Customer)
WITH collect(c) AS buyersOfTarget
MATCH (other:Product)
WHERE other.id <> $productId
  AND EXISTS {
    MATCH (buyer)-[:PURCHASED]->(other)
    WHERE buyer IN buyersOfTarget
  }
RETURN other.name AS alsoBought, other.category AS category
ORDER BY other.name
description: Set intersection using EXISTS subquery: finds products purchased by customers who also bought a given product, a classic collaborative filtering pattern.

cypher:
MATCH (n)
WHERE n:Employee AND n:Customer
RETURN n.name AS name, n.employeeId AS empId, n.customerId AS custId
ORDER BY n.name
description: Multi-label cross-reference: finds nodes that carry both the Employee and Customer labels, identifying internal users who are also customers.

cypher:
MATCH (a:Person {city: $city}), (b:Person {city: $city})
WHERE a.id < b.id AND NOT (a)-[:KNOWS]-(b)
RETURN a.name AS person1, b.name AS person2, $city AS city
ORDER BY a.name, b.name
LIMIT 50
description: Property-based cross-reference: finds pairs of people in the same city who do not yet know each other, useful for networking suggestions.

cypher:
MATCH (e1:Event), (e2:Event)
WHERE e1.id < e2.id
  AND e1.startDate <= e2.endDate
  AND e2.startDate <= e1.endDate
RETURN e1.name AS event1, e2.name AS event2,
       duration.between(date(e2.startDate), date(e1.endDate)).days AS overlapDays
ORDER BY overlapDays DESC
LIMIT 20
description: Temporal cross-reference: detects events with overlapping time windows by comparing start and end dates of all event pairs.
Negation cross-reference: finds customers who bought product A but have never purchased product B, useful for targeted upsell campaigns.

cypher:
MATCH (a:Person)-[:KNOWS]->(shared)<-[:KNOWS]-(b:Person)
WHERE a.id < b.id
WITH a, b, count(shared) AS sharedCount
ORDER BY sharedCount DESC
LIMIT $topN
RETURN a.name AS person1, b.name AS person2, sharedCount
description: Top-N by shared connections: ranks all pairs of people by their number of mutual acquaintances, a core pattern for link prediction and social network analysis.

cypher:
MATCH (u:User)
OPTIONAL MATCH (u)-[:PURCHASED]->(p:Product)
RETURN u.name AS user, count(p) AS purchaseCount
ORDER BY purchaseCount DESC
description: Cross-reference with OPTIONAL MATCH: returns all users alongside their purchase count, including users with zero purchases who would be excluded by a regular MATCH.

cypher:
MATCH (a:Company)-[:SUPPLIES]->(b:Company)
WHERE (a)-[:PARTNERS_WITH]->(b)
RETURN a.name AS supplier, b.name AS partner,
       [(a)-[s:SUPPLIES]->(b) | s.contractValue][0] AS supplyContract,
       [(a)-[pw:PARTNERS_WITH]->(b) | pw.since][0] AS partnerSince
ORDER BY supplyContract DESC
description: Multi-relationship cross-reference: finds company pairs connected by both SUPPLIES and PARTNERS_WITH relationships, returning attributes from each relationship type.

cypher:
MATCH (p:Product)-[:IN_CATEGORY]->(c:Category)
RETURN c.name AS category, count(p) AS productCount
ORDER BY productCount DESC
LIMIT 5
description: GROUP BY + COUNT + ORDER BY: classic aggregation returning the top 5 categories ranked by the number of products they contain.

cypher:
MATCH (a:Author)-[:WROTE]->(article:Article)-[:TAGGED]->(t:Tag)
RETURN a.name AS author, collect(DISTINCT t.name) AS uniqueTags
ORDER BY size(uniqueTags) DESC
description: COLLECT with DISTINCT: gathers the unique set of tags across all articles per author, eliminating duplicate tags from authors with multiple articles sharing the same tags.

cypher:
MATCH (s:Supplier)-[:PROVIDES]->(p:Part)-[:USED_IN]->(pr:Product)
RETURN s.name AS supplier, size(collect(DISTINCT pr.id)) AS distinctProductsSupplied
ORDER BY distinctProductsSupplied DESC
description: COLLECT + SIZE: counts distinct products each supplier contributes to by collecting distinct product IDs and measuring the list size.

cypher:
MATCH (d:Department)<-[:WORKS_IN]-(e:Employee)
WITH d.name AS department, count(e) AS headcount
RETURN avg(headcount) AS avgHeadcount, min(headcount) AS minHeadcount, max(headcount) AS maxHeadcount
description: Nested aggregation via WITH: first counts employees per department, then computes the average, minimum, and maximum headcount across all departments.

cypher:
MATCH (e:Employee)-[:WORKS_IN]->(d:Department)
RETURN d.name AS department, percentileCont(e.salary, 0.5) AS medianSalary
ORDER BY medianSalary DESC
description: percentileCont: computes the median (50th percentile) salary per department using continuous percentile interpolation.

cypher:
MATCH (o:Order)-[:PLACED_BY]->(c:Customer)
RETURN c.segment AS segment, round(stDev(o.amount), 2) AS amountStdDev, round(avg(o.amount), 2) AS avgAmount, count(o) AS orderCount
ORDER BY amountStdDev DESC
description: stDev: calculates the standard deviation of order amounts per customer segment alongside average and count, revealing spending variability.

cypher:
MATCH (s:Student)-[:ENROLLED_IN]->(c:Course)
WITH s.name AS student, collect(c.subject) AS subjects
UNWIND ['Math', 'Science', 'English'] AS requiredSubject
RETURN student, requiredSubject, CASE WHEN requiredSubject IN subjects THEN 'Enrolled' ELSE 'Missing' END AS status
ORDER BY student, requiredSubject
description: COLLECT + UNWIND pivot: pivots enrollment data by collecting subjects per student then unwinding a fixed list to produce a row-per-subject status matrix.

cypher:
MATCH (o:Order)-[:CONTAINS]->(li:LineItem)-[:FOR_PRODUCT]->(p:Product)
WITH o, count(li) AS itemCount, sum(li.quantity * li.unitPrice) AS orderTotal, avg(li.unitPrice) AS avgItemPrice
RETURN o.id AS orderId, itemCount, round(orderTotal, 2) AS total, round(avgItemPrice, 2) AS avgPrice
ORDER BY orderTotal DESC
LIMIT 25
description: Multiple aggregations: computes count, sum, and average in a single WITH clause for order line items, demonstrating efficient multi-metric aggregation.

cypher:
MATCH (t:Ticket)
RETURN
  count(CASE WHEN t.status = 'open' THEN 1 END) AS openCount,
  count(CASE WHEN t.status = 'in_progress' THEN 1 END) AS inProgressCount,
  count(CASE WHEN t.status = 'resolved' THEN 1 END) AS resolvedCount,
  count(CASE WHEN t.status = 'closed' THEN 1 END) AS closedCount,
  count(t) AS totalTickets
description: CASE WHEN conditional count: counts tickets by status category in a single pass without multiple MATCH clauses, producing a summary row with one column per status.

cypher:
MATCH (o:Order)
WHERE o.createdAt >= $startDate AND o.createdAt < $endDate
WITH date(o.createdAt) AS orderDate, o.amount AS amount
RETURN orderDate.year AS year, orderDate.month AS month,
       count(*) AS orderCount, round(sum(amount), 2) AS monthlyRevenue
ORDER BY year, month
description: Date-based grouping: groups orders by year and month using Neo4j date functions, computing monthly order count and revenue within a parameterized date range.

cypher:
MATCH (start:Person {name: $name})
CALL apoc.path.expandConfig(start, {
  relationshipFilter: 'KNOWS|WORKS_WITH>',
  labelFilter: '+Employee|/Contractor',
  minLevel: 1,
  maxLevel: 3,
  uniqueness: 'NODE_GLOBAL'
}) YIELD path
RETURN [n IN nodes(path) | n.name] AS chain, length(path) AS depth
ORDER BY depth

context: apoc.path.expandConfig with label and relationship filters

cypher:
MATCH (start:Server {hostname: $host})
CALL apoc.path.expandConfig(start, {
  relationshipFilter: 'CONNECTS_TO>|DEPENDS_ON>',
  minLevel: 1,
  maxLevel: 5,
  limit: 100
}) YIELD path
RETURN path

cypher:
MATCH (center:Customer {id: $customerId})
CALL apoc.path.subgraphAll(center, {
  maxLevel: 2,
  relationshipFilter: 'PURCHASED>|REVIEWED>|VIEWED>',
  labelFilter: '+Product|+Category'
}) YIELD nodes, relationships
RETURN [n IN nodes | {label: labels(n)[0], name: n.name}] AS subNodes,
       size(relationships) AS relCount
description: Extract the complete 2-hop neighborhood around a customer including their purchases, reviews, and viewed products

cypher:
MATCH (root:Department {name: $dept})
CALL apoc.path.spanningTree(root, {
  relationshipFilter: 'REPORTS_TO>|MANAGES>',
  labelFilter: '+Employee|+Manager',
  maxLevel: 6
}) YIELD path
RETURN [n IN nodes(path) | n.name] AS orgChain, length(path) AS depth
ORDER BY depth
description: Build an organizational spanning tree from a department root following management hierarchy

cypher:
MATCH (a:Airport {code: $from}), (b:Airport {code: $to})
CALL apoc.algo.allSimplePaths(a, b, 'FLIES_TO>', 4) YIELD path
RETURN [n IN nodes(path) | n.code] AS route,
       reduce(cost = 0, r IN relationships(path) | cost + r.price) AS totalPrice
ORDER BY totalPrice
LIMIT 5
description: Find all simple paths between two airports with up to 4 hops and calculate total flight cost

cypher:
MATCH (p1:Project {name: $project1})-[:USES]->(t1:Technology)
WITH collect(t1.name) AS techSet1
MATCH (p2:Project {name: $project2})-[:USES]->(t2:Technology)
WITH techSet1, collect(t2.name) AS techSet2
RETURN apoc.coll.toSet(techSet1) AS project1Tech,
       apoc.coll.toSet(techSet2) AS project2Tech,
       apoc.coll.intersection(techSet1, techSet2) AS sharedTech
description: Deduplicate technology lists for two projects and find their intersection using set operations

cypher:
MATCH (d:Document)-[:HAS_KEYWORD]->(k:Keyword)
WITH d, collect(k.name) AS keywords
WITH d, apoc.coll.sort(apoc.coll.toSet(keywords)) AS sortedKeywords
MATCH (d)-[:IN_SECTION]->(s:Section)-[:HAS_TAG]->(t:Tag)
WITH d, sortedKeywords, s, collect(t.name) AS sectionTags
WITH d, sortedKeywords, collect(sectionTags) AS nestedTags
RETURN d.title, sortedKeywords, apoc.coll.flatten(nestedTags) AS allTags
description: Sort and deduplicate keyword lists and flatten nested tag collections from document sections using two-step aggregation
Batch-archive products not updated in 90 days using periodic iterate for safe large-scale updates

cypher:
MATCH (c:Category)-[:CONTAINS]->(p:Product)-[:SOLD_IN]->(r:Region)
WITH c, r, count(p) AS productCount, sum(p.revenue) AS totalRevenue
WITH c, collect({region: r, products: productCount, revenue: totalRevenue}) AS regionData
CALL apoc.create.vNode(['Summary'], {category: c.name, regions: size(regionData)}) YIELD node AS summary
WITH summary, regionData
UNWIND regionData AS rd
CALL apoc.create.vRelationship(summary, 'HAS_REGION', {products: rd.products, revenue: rd.revenue}, rd.region) YIELD rel
RETURN summary, collect(rel) AS regionRels
description: Create virtual nodes and relationships for an aggregated category-region summary without persisting data
context: apoc.create.vNode / apoc.create.vRelationship for virtual graph projections

cypher:
MATCH (p:Person)
WITH p.email AS email, collect(p) AS duplicates
WHERE size(duplicates) > 1
CALL apoc.refactor.mergeNodes(duplicates, {
  properties: 'combine',
  mergeRels: true
}) YIELD node
RETURN node.name, node.email, size(keys(node)) AS propertyCount
description: Merge duplicate person nodes by email address, combining properties and merging relationships

cypher:
MATCH (o:Order)-[:CONTAINS]->(i:Item)-[:IS_PRODUCT]->(p:Product)
WHERE o.date >= date($startDate) AND o.date <= date($endDate)
WITH o, collect({product: p.name, quantity: i.quantity, price: i.unitPrice}) AS items
RETURN apoc.convert.toJson({orderId: o.id, date: toString(o.date), items: items}) AS jsonExport
description: Export order data as JSON strings for integration with external systems

cypher:
CALL apoc.meta.graph() YIELD nodes, relationships
RETURN [n IN nodes | {label: apoc.node.labels(n)[0], count: n.count}] AS nodeTypes,
       [r IN relationships | {type: type(r), count: r.count}] AS relTypes
description: Introspect the graph schema to discover all node labels, relationship types, and their counts

cypher:
MATCH (center:Location {name: $location})
CALL apoc.neighbors.tohop(center, 'CONNECTED_TO>|NEAR>', 3) YIELD node
RETURN node.name AS nearby, labels(node) AS types
ORDER BY node.name
description: Find all nodes within 3 hops of a location through spatial connectivity relationships

cypher:
CALL apoc.load.json($apiUrl) YIELD value
UNWIND value.results AS record
MERGE (c:Company {id: record.id})
ON CREATE SET c.name = record.name,
              c.industry = record.industry,
              c.founded = date(record.founded),
              c.importedAt = datetime()
ON MATCH SET c.name = record.name,
             c.updatedAt = datetime()
RETURN count(c) AS companiesProcessed
description: Import company data from a REST API JSON endpoint and merge into the graph with upsert logic

cypher:
MATCH (n:Task {id: $taskId})
CALL apoc.do.when(
  n.status = 'completed',
  'SET n.closedAt = datetime(), n.active = false RETURN n',
  'SET n.retryCount = coalesce(n.retryCount, 0) + 1 RETURN n',
  {n: n}
) YIELD value
RETURN value.n.status AS status, value.n.retryCount AS retries
description: Conditionally close or retry a task based on its current status using apoc.do.when
Project a bipartite person-project graph with node properties and weighted relationships into GDS memory
context: gds.graph.project with node and relationship projections

cypher:
CALL gds.pageRank.stream('collaboration-graph', {
  maxIterations: 20,
  dampingFactor: 0.85,
  relationshipWeightProperty: 'hours'
}) YIELD nodeId, score
WITH gds.util.asNode(nodeId) AS node, score
WHERE 'Person' IN labels(node)
SET node.pageRank = score
RETURN node.name AS person, score
ORDER BY score DESC
LIMIT 20
description: Run PageRank on a collaboration graph weighted by hours and write scores back to Person nodes
context: gds.pageRank.stream + write back to node property

cypher:
CALL gds.louvain.stream('social-network', {
  relationshipWeightProperty: 'strength',
  includeIntermediateCommunities: false,
  maxLevels: 10,
  maxIterations: 10
}) YIELD nodeId, communityId
WITH communityId, collect(gds.util.asNode(nodeId).name) AS members
RETURN communityId, members, size(members) AS communitySize
ORDER BY communitySize DESC
LIMIT 20
description: Detect communities in a social network using Louvain with weighted relationships and report membership

cypher:
CALL gds.betweenness.stream('infrastructure-graph', {
  samplingSize: 500,
  samplingSeed: 42
}) YIELD nodeId, score
WITH gds.util.asNode(nodeId) AS node, score
WHERE score > 0
RETURN node.hostname AS server, labels(node) AS roles, score AS betweenness
ORDER BY betweenness DESC
LIMIT 15
description: Identify infrastructure bottleneck servers with highest betweenness centrality scores

cypher:
CALL gds.nodeSimilarity.stream('product-graph', {
  topK: 10,
  similarityCutoff: 0.25,
  degreeCutoff: 2
}) YIELD node1, node2, similarity
RETURN gds.util.asNode(node1).name AS product1,
       gds.util.asNode(node2).name AS product2,
       round(similarity * 1000) / 1000 AS similarity
ORDER BY similarity DESC
LIMIT 20
description: Find the most similar products based on shared customer purchases using Jaccard similarity with topK filtering

cypher:
MATCH (src:City {name: $origin}), (dst:City {name: $destination})
CALL gds.shortestPath.dijkstra.stream('transport-network', {
  sourceNode: src,
  targetNode: dst,
  relationshipWeightProperty: 'travelTime'
}) YIELD totalCost, nodeIds, costs, path
RETURN totalCost AS totalTravelTime,
       [id IN nodeIds | gds.util.asNode(id).name] AS route,
       costs AS legTimes
description: Find the fastest route between two cities using Dijkstra weighted by travel time

cypher:
CALL gds.wcc.stream('supply-chain-graph') YIELD nodeId, componentId
WITH componentId, collect(gds.util.asNode(nodeId).name) AS members
RETURN componentId, members, size(members) AS componentSize
ORDER BY componentSize DESC
description: Identify disconnected clusters in a supply chain graph using weakly connected components

cypher:
CALL gds.labelPropagation.stream('customer-graph', {
  maxIterations: 10,
  nodeWeightProperty: 'purchaseVolume',
  relationshipWeightProperty: 'transactionCount'
}) YIELD nodeId, communityId
WITH communityId, collect(gds.util.asNode(nodeId).name) AS customers
RETURN communityId, customers, size(customers) AS segmentSize
ORDER BY segmentSize DESC
LIMIT 10
description: Segment customers into communities using label propagation weighted by purchase behavior

cypher:
CALL gds.triangleCount.stream('social-network') YIELD nodeId, triangleCount
WITH gds.util.asNode(nodeId) AS person, triangleCount
WHERE triangleCount > 0
RETURN person.name, triangleCount
ORDER BY triangleCount DESC
LIMIT 15
description: Count triangles per person to identify tightly clustered social groups

cypher:
CALL gds.graph.filter(
  'recent-citations',
  'article-citations',
  'n.published >= date("2024-01-01")',
  'r.relevance > 0.5'
) YIELD graphName, nodeCount, relationshipCount
RETURN graphName, nodeCount, relationshipCount
description: Filter an existing in-memory GDS graph by node and relationship predicates to create a focused subgraph for analysis
context: gds.graph.filter for subgraph extraction (replaces deprecated Cypher projection)

description: Estimate memory requirements before projecting a large graph to prevent out-of-memory errors

cypher:
CALL gds.graph.list() YIELD graphName, nodeCount, relationshipCount, memoryUsage
RETURN graphName, nodeCount, relationshipCount, memoryUsage
ORDER BY memoryUsage DESC
description: List all projected in-memory graphs with their sizes before dropping to free memory
